etymologies: Old English furthor (adverb), furthra (adjective), fyrthrian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to forth

notes.text: Is there any difference between further and farther in she moved further down the train and she moved farther down the train? Both words share the same roots: in the sentences given above, where the sense is ‘at, to, or by a greater distance’, there is no difference in meaning, and both are equally correct. Further is a much commoner word, though, and is in addition used in various abstract and metaphorical contexts, for example referring to time, in which farther is unusual, e.g. without further delay; have you anything further to say?; we intend to stay a further two weeks. The same distinction is made between farthest and furthest: the farthest point from the sun versus this first team has gone furthest in its analysis

definitions: at, to, or by a greater distance (used to indicate the extent to which one thing or person is or becomes distant from another).

examples.text: for some time I had wanted to move further from London
the EU seems to have moved further away from the original aims

shortDefinitions: at, to, or by greater distance

definitions: used to emphasize the difference between a supposed or suggested fact or state of mind and the truth

examples.text: as for her being a liar, nothing could be further from the truth
nothing could be further from his mind than marrying

shortDefinitions: suggesting difference between supposed fact and truth

definitions: over a greater expanse of space or time; for a longer way

examples.text: we had walked further than I realized
wages have been driven down even further

shortDefinitions: over greater expanse of space or time

definitions: beyond the point already reached or the distance already covered

examples.text: Amelie decided to drive further up the coast
before going any further we need to define our terms
this theme will be developed further in Chapter 6

definitions: at or to a more advanced, successful, or desirable stage

examples.text: determination could not get her any further
at the end of three years they were no further on

shortDefinitions: at or to more advanced or desirable stage

definitions: used to introduce a new point relating to or reinforcing a previous statement

examples.text: On the internet, the size and scope of the market is several orders of magnitude higher. Further, it is available 24 hours per day, 7 days per week

shortDefinitions: introducing point relating to previous statement

notes.text: Is there any difference between further and farther in she moved further down the train and she moved farther down the train? Both words share the same roots: in the sentences given above, where the sense is ‘at, to, or by a greater distance’, there is no difference in meaning, and both are equally correct. Further is a much commoner word, though, and is in addition used in various abstract and metaphorical contexts, for example referring to time, in which farther is unusual, e.g. without further delay; have you anything further to say?; we intend to stay a further two weeks. The same distinction is made between farthest and furthest: the farthest point from the sun versus this first team has gone furthest in its analysis

definitions: more distant in space than something else of the same kind

examples.text: two men were standing at the further end of the clearing

definitions: more remote from a central point

examples.text: the museum is in the further reaches of the town

definitions: additional to what already exists or has already taken place, been done, or been accounted for

examples.text: cook for a further ten minutes

shortDefinitions: additional to what already exists or has happened

notes.text: Is there any difference between further and farther in she moved further down the train and she moved farther down the train? Both words share the same roots: in the sentences given above, where the sense is ‘at, to, or by a greater distance’, there is no difference in meaning, and both are equally correct. Further is a much commoner word, though, and is in addition used in various abstract and metaphorical contexts, for example referring to time, in which farther is unusual, e.g. without further delay; have you anything further to say?; we intend to stay a further two weeks. The same distinction is made between farthest and furthest: the farthest point from the sun versus this first team has gone furthest in its analysis

definitions: help the progress or development of (something); promote

examples.text: he had depended on using them to further his own career
